definition_vi: mainly, especially
examples_vi: Above all, don't mention the matter to Gerard
he's the last person we should tell. Sheila does well in all her school subjects, but above all in mathematics. Her math scores are always over 95 percent.

definition_vi: in the order of; on the authority of
examples_vi: The students on the football team were ranked according to height, from shortest to tallest. According to my dictionary, you are using that word in your essay incorrectly.

definition_vi: all the time, from the beginning
examples_vi: She knew all along that we'd never agree with his plan. You're smiling! Did you know all along that I'd give you a birthday present?

definition_vi: the entire day, week, month, year
examples_vi: I've been working on my income tax forms all day long. I've hardly had time to eat. It's been raining all week long. We haven't seen the sun since last Monday.

definition_vi: considering everything
examples_vi: There were a few problems, but all in all it was a well-organized seminar. Leonard got a low grade in one subject, but all in all he's a good student.

definition_vi: suddenly, without warning
examples_vi: All of a sudden Ed appeared at the door. We weren't expecting him to drop by. All at once Millie got up and left the house without any explanation.

definition_vi: acceptable, fine; yes, okay
examples_vi: He said that it would be all right to wait in her office until she returned. Do you want me to turn off the TV? Alright, if you insist.

definition_vi: a hopeless case, a person or situation having no hope of positive change
examples_vi: It seems that Charles will never listen to our advice. I suppose it's a lost cause. The police searched for the missing girl for two weeks, but finally gave it up as a lost cause. Children who have committed several crimes as teenagers and show no sorrow about their actions are generally lost causes.

definition_vi: really, actually
examples_vi: Hans thinks he knows English well but, as a matter of fact, he speaks very poorly. I didn't say that. In fact, I said quite the opposite.

definition_vi: regarding, concerning
examples_vi: As for the money, we will simply have to borrow some more from the bank. There is no doubt as to her intelligence
she's the smartest one in the class.

definition_vi: just after, when
examples_vi: As soon as it started to snow, the children ran outside with big smiles on their faces. I'm busy now, but I'll meet you as soon as I've finished this work.

definition_vi: very inexpensive, a bargain
examples_vi: I can't believe that I paid only $2,000 for this three-year-old car. What a steal! Scott considered it a steal when he bought a complete bedroom set for only $99.

definition_vi: as is the general case, as is typical
examples_vi: George is late for class as usual. This seems to happen every day. As usual, Dora received first prize in the swimming contest. It's the third consecutive year that she has won.

definition_vi: to any degree
examples_vi: Larry isn't at all shy about expressing his opinions. When I asked Donna whether she was tired, she said, "Not in the least. I'm full of energy."

definition_vi: in the beginning, originally
examples_vi: At first English was difficult for him, but later he made great progress. I thought at first that it was Sheila calling, but then I realized that it was Betty.

definition_vi: basically, fundamentally
examples_vi: James sometimes seems quite unfriendly, but at heart he's a good person. The Fares often don't see eye to eye, but at heart they both love each other very much.

definition_vi: finally, after a long time
examples_vi: We waited for hours and then the train arrived at last. Now that I am sixteen, at last I can drive my parents' car.

definition_vi: a minimum of, no fewer than
examples_vi: I spend at least two hours every night on my studies. Mike claims that he drinks at least a quart of water every day.

definition_vi: in a backward and forward motion
examples_vi: The restless lion kept pacing back and forth along the front of its cage. Grandmother finds it relaxing to sit in her rocking chair and move back and forth.

definition_vi: ready to, just going to
examples_vi: We were about to leave the house when the phone rang. I'm sorry that I broke in. What were you about to say?

definition_vi: having contact
examples_vi: James will be in touch with us soon to relay the details of the plan. I certainly enjoyed seeing you again after all these years. Let's be sure to keep in touch.

definition_vi: be attentive, competent, alert
examples_vi: Jim was the only one who caught that serious error in the bookkeeping statements. He's really on the ball. Ella was certainly on the ball when she remembered to reconfirm our flight arrangements. All the rest of us would have forgotten.

definition_vi: certainly, definitely, naturally ; using any possible way or method
examples_vi: If the Johnsons invite us for dinner, then by all means we have to return the invitation. Of course, we don't have to invite their children, too. In order to ensure its survival, the ailing company has to obtain an infusion of cash by all means.

definition_vi: by a great margin, clearly
examples_vi: Jacquie is by far the most intelligent student in our class. This is by far the hottest, most humid summer we've had in years.

definition_vi: by memorizing
examples_vi: He knows many passages from Shakespeare by heart. Do you know all the idioms you have studied in this book by heart?

definition_vi: alone, without assistance
examples_vi: Francis translated that French novel by himself. No one helped him. Paula likes to walk through the woods by herself, but her brother prefers to walk with a companion.

definition_vi: incidentally
examples_vi: Movies are my favorite form of entertainment. Oh, by the way, have you seen the new picture that's playing at the Bijou? Vera's been divorced for three years now. She told me, by the way, that she never plans to remarry.

definition_vi: clearly stated, definite, apparent
examples_vi: The president's message was clear-cut: the company had to reduce personnel immediately. Professor Larsen is well known for his interesting and clear-cut presentations.

definition_vi: a situation involving a narrow escape from danger
examples_vi: Bob, that car nearly hit us! What a close call. We had a close call when a small fire in our kitchen almost spread to the rest of the house.

definition_vi: predictable, known beforehand; boring
examples_vi: The results of the national election were rather cut and dried
the Republicans won easily. A job on a factory assembly line is certainly cut and dried.

definition_vi: continuously, constantly
examples_vi: During the month of April, it rained day in and day out. Day after day I waited for a letter from him, but one never came. Year in and year out, the weather in San Diego is the best in the nation.

definition_vi: rehearsal, practice session
examples_vi: The college president requested a dry run of the graduation ceremony in order to ensure that all aspects went smoothly. Before the manager presented the reorganizational plans to the board of directors, he did several dry runs of his presentation.

definition_vi: every second
examples_vi: I play tennis with my father every other Saturday, so I usually play twice a month. There were twenty problems in the exercise, but the teacher told us only to do every other one. Actually, doing ten problems was difficult enough.

definition_vi: direct, personal; directly, personally
examples_vi: The workers' representatives had a face-to-face meeting with the management to resolve the salary issue. The stepmother and her teenage son talked face to face about his troubles in school.

definition_vi: not frequent, unusual, rare
examples_vi: The times that our children get to stay up late are few and far between. Airplane travel is very safe because accidents are few and far between.

definition_vi: divided into two equal parts
examples_vi: Let's go fifty-fifty on the cost of a new rug for our apartment. The political candidate has a fifty-fifty chance of winning the election.

definition_vi: excellent, superb
examples_vi: The food served in that four-star restaurant is truly first-rate. The Beverly Hills Hotel provides first-rate service to its guests.

definition_vi: permanently, forever
examples_vi: Ruth has returned to Canada for good. She won't ever live in the United States again. Are you finished with school for good, or will you continue your studies some day?

definition_vi: this one time, for only one time
examples_vi: For once I was able to win a game of golf against Steve, who is a much better player than I am. Dad, for once would you please let me drive the new car?

definition_vi: without doubt
examples_vi: In the dark, I couldn't tell for sure whether it was Polly or Sarah who drove by. I know for certain that Gene will move back to Washington next month.

definition_vi: temporarily
examples_vi: For the time being, Janet is working as a waitress, but she really hopes to become an actress soon. We're living in an apartment for now, but soon we'll be looking for a house to buy.

definition_vi: from this time into the future
examples_vi: Mr. Lee's doctor told him to cut down on eating fatty foods from now on, or else he might suffer heart disease. I'm sorry that I dropped by at a bad time. From now on I'll call you first.

definition_vi: compromise, cooperation between people
examples_vi: Give and take is an important element of a successful marriage. Most business negotiations involve give and take between the parties involved.

definition_vi: should, ought to, be advisable to
examples_vi: I think you'd better speak to Mr. White right away about this matter. The doctor told the patient that he'd better go home and rest.

definition_vi: partially deaf, not able to hear well
examples_vi: You'll have to speak a little louder. Mrs. Evans is hard of hearing. Please don't shout. I'm not hard of hearing. Listening to loud music too much can make you hard of hearing.

definition_vi: to have, to possess
examples_vi: Curtis has got a bad cold. He's sneezing and coughing a lot. How much money have you got with you right now?

definition_vi: must
examples_vi: She has got to go to Chicago today to sign the contract papers. I have to be back home by two o'clock or my wife will feel ill at ease.

definition_vi: uncomfortable or worried in a situation
examples_vi: Speaking in front of a large audience makes many people feel ill at ease. My wife and I were ill at ease because our daughter was late coming home from a date.

definition_vi: hurried, rushed
examples_vi: Alex seems in a hurry
he must be late for his train again. She's always in a rush in the morning to get the kids to school.

definition_vi: in order to be prepared if
examples_vi: You'd better close the windows in case it rains. We should be sure to leave for the airport early, just in case. Cynthia, take one of your books in case you have some time to read on our trip.

definition_vi: under firm control, well managed
examples_vi: The copilot asked the pilot if he had the plane in hand or whether he needed any help navigating through the severe thunderstorm. The police officer radioed to the station that she had the emergency situation in hand and didn't require any assistance.

definition_vi: very quickly, rapidly
examples_vi: Mac said that he'd be ready to leave in no time. We thought that the meeting would take two hours, but it was over in no time at all.

definition_vi: with the inside facing the outside
examples_vi: Someone should tell little Bobby that his shirt is inside out. The high winds ruined the umbrella by blowing it inside out.

definition_vi: eventually, after a long period of time
examples_vi: In the long run, the synthetic weave in this carpet will wear better than the woolen one. You won't have to replace it so soon. If you work hard at your marriage, you'll find out that, in the long run, your spouse can be your best friend in life.

definition_vi: very much, greatly
examples_vi: Jim and Claudia want to have children in the worst way. They are trying very hard to conceive. Because Umer has relatives in Turkey, he wants to visit there in the worst way.

definition_vi: before the time necessary to do something
examples_vi: We entered the theater just in time to see the beginning of the movie. The truck was not able to stop in time to prevent an accident.

definition_vi: useless, without the desired result
examples_vi: All the doctors' efforts to save the injured woman were in vain. She was declared dead three hours after being admitted to the hospital. We tried in vain to reach you last night. Is your phone out of order?

definition_vi: it seems likely, reasonable, or typical
examples_vi: It figures that the children were willing to help with the yardwork only if they received a reward for doing so. When I told Evan that his secretary was unhappy about not getting a raise, he said that it figured.

definition_vi: and certainly not
examples_vi: I'm too sick today to walk to the kitchen, let alone go to the zoo with you. He doesn't even speak his own language well, let alone French.

definition_vi: gradually, slowly
examples_vi: Karen's health seems to be improving little by little. If you study regularly each day, step by step your vocabulary will increase.

definition_vi: approximately, almost; somewhat, to a certain degree
examples_vi: Although your bedroom feels smaller, it's more or less the same size as mine. Ted more or less agreed with our decision to put off the meeting until more members could show up. At least he didn't object strongly.

definition_vi: not willing to accept the ideas of others
examples_vi: Narrow-minded people tend to discriminate against groups of people with which they have nothing in common. Ted is so broad-minded that he has almost no standards by which he judges others.

definition_vi: don't be concerned about it; ignore what was just said
examples_vi: When he spilled his drink on my coat, I said, "Never mind. It needs to be cleaned anyway." So you weren't listening to me again. Never mind
it wasn't important.

definition_vi: regardless of
examples_vi: No matter how much money he spends on his clothes, he never looks well dressed. No matter where that escaped prisoner tries to hide, the police will find him sooner or later.

definition_vi: absolutely not
examples_vi: You're asking me to invest in that poorly rated company just because you know the son of the president? Not on your life! When a friend tried to get Mark to jump out of a plane with a parachute, he immediately responded, "No way!"

definition_vi: occasionally, sometimes
examples_vi: I don't see him very often, but (every) now and then we arrange to have lunch together. Gary gets a cold (every) once in a while even though he takes good care of himself. Every so often my brother and I get together for a camping trip. I like to sleep late in the morning from time to time.

definition_vi: it's no surprise that, not surprisingly
examples_vi: No wonder the portable heater doesn't work. It's not plugged into the electrical outlet! Jack has been out of town for several weeks. No wonder we haven't seen him recently.

definition_vi: finally, absolutely
examples_vi: My daughter told her boyfriend once and for all that she wouldn't date him anymore. Once and for all, John has quit smoking cigarettes.

definition_vi: rarely, infrequently
examples_vi: Snow falls on the city of San Diego, California, once in a blue moon. Once in a blue moon my wife and I eat at a very expensive restaurant.

definition_vi: nervous, anxious; upset, irritable
examples_vi: Cynthia was on edge all day about the important presentation she had to give to the local citizens group. I don't like being around Jake when he's on edge like that. Someone should tell him to calm down and relax.

definition_vi: available, nearby
examples_vi: I always keep some extra money on hand in case I forget to get cash from the bank. The concert organizers arranged to have some security guards on hand in case there were any problems during the performance.

definition_vi: alert, cautious
examples_vi: It's important for all the players on a soccer team to stay on their toes. We'd better keep on our toes while we're walking along the dark portions of this street.

definition_vi: for a reason, deliberately
examples_vi: Do you think that she didn't come to the meeting on purpose? It was no accident that he broke my glasses. He did it on purpose.

definition_vi: however, in contrast
examples_vi: Democracies provide people many freedoms and privileges. On the other hand, democracies suffer many serious problems such as crime and unemployment. My sister takes after my father in appearance. On the other hand, I take after my mother.

definition_vi: in general, in most ways
examples_vi: He is, on the whole, a good student. By and large, I agree with your suggestions.

definition_vi: exactly at the correct time, punctually
examples_vi: I thought that Margaret would arrive late, but she was right on time. Did you get to work on time this morning, or did rush hour traffic delay you?

definition_vi: not modern, not current, not timely; no longer available in published form
examples_vi: Many people buy new cars when their old cars become out of date. I don't know why Gene likes to wear out-of-date clothing. His clothes are so outdated that even his girlfriend hesitates to be seen with him. This book can't be ordered any more because it is out of date.

definition_vi: not in working condition
examples_vi: The elevator was out of order, so we had to walk to the tenth floor of the building. We couldn't use the soft drink machine because it was out of order.

definition_vi: impossible, not feasible
examples_vi: Stephen told Deborah that it was out of the question for her to borrow his new car. Don't expect me to do that again. It's absolutely out of the question.

definition_vi: not having contact; not having knowledge of
examples_vi: Marge and I had been out of touch for years, but then suddenly she called me up the other day. Larry has been so busy that he seems out of touch with world events.

definition_vi: repeatedly
examples_vi: The actress studied her lines in the movie over and over until she knew them well. Children have difficulty remembering rules, so it's often necessary to repeat them over and over again. Time and again I have to remind Bobby to put on his seatbelt in the car.

definition_vi: many
examples_vi: Quite a few students were absent yesterday
in fact, more than half of them were not there. We did not expect many people to attend the affair, but quite a few of our friends actually came.

definition_vi: very soon; immediately
examples_vi: Dad says that dinner will be ready right away, so we'd better wash our hands and set the table. Tell Will to come to my office right away. I must see him immediately. Stop playing that loud music at once!

definition_vi: I don't know
examples_vi: When Elmer asked his wife if she knew why the new neighbors left their garage door open all night, she responded, "Search me." When I asked Dereck why his girlfriend wasn't at the party yet, he said, "Beats me. I expected her an hour ago."

definition_vi: until now, until the present time
examples_vi: So far, this year has been excellent for business. I hope that the good luck continues. How many idioms have we studied in this book up to now? As of yet, we have not had an answer from him.

definition_vi: eventually, after a period of time
examples_vi: If you study English seriously, sooner or later you'll become fluent. I'm too tired to do my homework now
I'm sure I'll do it sooner or later.

definition_vi: to be clear and logical
examples_vi: It stands to reason that a person without experience cannot do the work as well as an experienced one. It stands to reason that he isn't going to pass the course if he never studies.

definition_vi: the final event in a series of unacceptable actions
examples_vi: When John asked to borrow money from me for the fourth time, it was the last straw. I finally told him that I couldn't lend him any more. I can't believe that my roommate left the door to our apartment unlocked again. It's the last straw
I'm moving out.

definition_vi: to deserve, to receive a just punishment
examples_vi: If you drink alcohol and then drive a car, you're only asking for trouble. Don't complain about your cut in salary. You asked for it by refusing to heed our repeated warnings not to be late and inefficient.

definition_vi: to drive a vehicle out of a parking space ; to withdraw support, to fail to fulfill a promise or obligation
examples_vi: The parking lot attendant had to back another car out before he could get to mine. We were all ready to sign the contracts when one of the parties to the agreement backed out.

definition_vi: to drive or go backwards ; to return to a previous thought
examples_vi: I couldn't back my car up because there was a bicycle in the driveway behind me. Ursula asked her friends to go back her up when she went to court to fight a ticket for an illegal lane change on the highway. Wait a minute. Could you back up and say that again?

word: to be about to do something
definition_vi: to be at the moment of doing something, to be ready
examples_vi: I was just about to leave when you telephoned. Oh, hi, John. We're just about to eat dinner.

word: to be a far cry from
definition_vi: to be very different from
examples_vi: I enjoyed visiting Seattle, but it was a far cry from the ideal vacation spot I expected. Ned is enjoying his new job, but his responsibilities are a far cry from what he was told they would be.

definition_vi: to avoid discussing directly, to evade the issue
examples_vi: Our boss beats around the bush so much that no one in the office knows exactly what he wants us to do. Instead of beating around the bush, Melinda explained her objection in very clear terms.

definition_vi: to be in a more favorable condition or situation
examples_vi: Jim would be better off staying at home because of his cold. You'd be much better off working in an office than in a factory. The economies of some nations are worse off than they were several decades ago.

word: to be bound to do something
definition_vi: to be certain to do something, to be sure to do something
examples_vi: We are bound to be late if you don't hurry up. With the economy improving now, their business is bound to make more money this year.

definition_vi: to be greatly affected by a strong feeling
examples_vi: Paula and Leanne were carried away by the sad movie that they saw together. James got carried away with anger when his roommate crashed his new car into a telephone pole.

definition_vi: to happen to
examples_vi: What has become of my pencil? I had it ten minutes ago, but now I can't find it. I wondered what became of you. I looked around the shopping center for two hours, but I couldn't find you at all.

definition_vi: to have the necessary skills or talent for
examples_vi: John is certainly not cut out for the work of a trial lawyer. Are you certain that you are cut out for that kind of job?

definition_vi: to be victimized or cheated
examples_vi: When the jeweler confirmed that the diamonds that the woman had purchased abroad were really fake, she exclaimed, "I've been had!" The angry customer complained about being overcharged at the store, asserting that this was the third time that he had been had.

definition_vi: to be popular or fashionable; to be available at one's work or home
examples_vi: Most young people tend to want anything that is in at the time, but a few don't care about current trends. Could you please tell me when Mrs. Zachary will be in? I'd like to talk to her soon.

definition_vi: to manage, to have responsibility for
examples_vi: Jane is in charge of the office while Mrs. Haig is on a business trip. Who is in charge of arrangements for the dance next week?

definition_vi: to be in another person's position, to face the same situation as another person
examples_vi: If I were in your shoes, I wouldn't take too many classes this semester. When his boss finds out about that accounting error, I wouldn't want to be in his shoes.

definition_vi: to block or obstruct; not to be helpful, to cause inconvenience
examples_vi: Jocelyn couldn't drive through the busy intersection because a big truck was in the way. Our small child tried to help us paint the house, but actually he just got in our way.

definition_vi: to accept as true, have faith in
examples_vi: Some people believe in being honest in all human affairs, while others accept the need to lie in order to get one's way. Throughout the history of man, some cultures have believed in one god while others have believed in the existence of many gods.

definition_vi: to appear promising or optimistic, to be improving
examples_vi: The board chairman is glad to report that things are looking up for the company after several years of declining sales. Prospects for building that new library in the downtown area are looking up.

definition_vi: to be unpopular or no longer in fashion; to be away from one's work or home
examples_vi: These days, designer jeans are in and long skirts are out. I'm sorry, Mr. Jensen is out at the moment. Could I take a message?

definition_vi: to be finished, to end
examples_vi: After the dance was over, we all went to a restaurant. The meeting was through ten minutes earlier than everyone expected.

definition_vi: to be very busy, to have too much to do ; to be beyond one's ability to understand
examples_vi: I'd love to take a week off for a hiking trip, but at the moment I am over my head in work. Maybe next week when I'm only up to my ears! It was impossible for the tutor to get through to Bill about the physics problem because the subject matter was over Bill's head.

definition_vi: to be unsatisfactory, to be improper, to be wrong
examples_vi: A: What is the matter, Betty? You look very upset. B: Yes, something is the matter. I've lost my purse! A: Is something the matter, Charles? You don't look well. B: No, nothing is the matter. I'm just a little under the weather.

definition_vi: to expire, to be finished
examples_vi: "The time is up," the teacher said at the end of the test period. We have to leave the tennis court because our hour is up
some other people want to use it now.

definition_vi: to become available to others
examples_vi: When one of the full-time contract instructors stepped down, her nice office overlooking the river was up for grabs. Did you know that Senator Stone is retiring and that her Senate seat is up for grabs?

definition_vi: to be responsible for deciding; to be doing as a regular activity
examples_vi: I don't care whether we go to the reception or not. It's up to you. Hi, George. I haven't seen you in a while. What have you been up to?

definition_vi: to be doing something; to be planning or plotting something, scheming
examples_vi: Hi, Jake. I haven't seen you in a long time. What have you been up to? Those boys hiding behind the building must be up to something bad.

definition_vi: be accustomed to
examples_vi: He is used to this climate now, so the changes in temperature do not affect him much. I am used to studying in the library, so it's difficult for me to study at home now.

definition_vi: to have enough money to enjoy a comfortable life, to be rich
examples_vi: They live in the best section of town in a large home
they are very well-off. By the time I reach the age of fifty-five, I hope to be well-to-do and to travel frequently.

definition_vi: to be able to focus or concentrate on
examples_vi: Jack's really with it today. I've never seen him play such good soccer. You've done only a small amount of work in two hours. You're not with it today, are you? It's no excuse to say that you feel out of it. We need everyone's help on this, so get with it!

definition_vi: to support, to back ; to understand or follow what someone is saying
examples_vi: Although others thought that we shouldn't go along with Jerry, I told Jerry that I was with him on his proposal for reorganizing the staff. After turning left at the traffic light, go two blocks and turn right on Madison. After three more blocks, turn right again. Are you still with me?

definition_vi: to accept as a responsibility or task
examples_vi: When I accepted the position of chairman, I didn't realize how much I was biting off. When James registered for 18 units in his last semester at college, he bit off more than he could chew.

definition_vi: to explode, to go flat
examples_vi: On our trip to Colorado, one of the car tires blew out when it hit a large hole in the road. Little Joey wasn't able to blow all the candles out, so his big sister helped him.

definition_vi: to inflate, to fill with air
examples_vi: Daddy, could you please blow up this balloon for me? When the airplane crashed into the ground, it blew up immediately. The military had to blow the missile up in midair when it started to go the wrong way.

definition_vi: to stop doing as a regular activity, to remove oneself from a situation
examples_vi: She bowed out as the school's registrar after sixteen years of service. One of the two partners wanted out of the deal because they couldn't agree on the terms of the contract.

definition_vi: to stop functioning
examples_vi: I just bought my new car yesterday and already it has broken down. The elevator broke down, so we walked all the way up to the top floor.

definition_vi: gradually to prepare something for use that is new and stiff
examples_vi: It is best to break a new car in by driving it slowly for the first few hundred miles. While Carrie and I were talking, Bill broke in to tell me about a telephone call. Peter, it's very impolite to cut in like that while others are speaking.

definition_vi: to become free or loose, to escape
examples_vi: During the bad storm, the boat broke loose from the landing and drifted out to sea. One bicyclist broke loose from the pack of racers and pulled ahead towards the finish line.

definition_vi: to terminate, to discontinue
examples_vi: After war began, the two countries broke off diplomatic relations. Elsa and Bob were once engaged, but they have already broken it off.

definition_vi: to become widespread suddenly
examples_vi: An epidemic of measles broke out in Chicago this past week. If a nuclear war ever breaks out, it is unlikely that many people will survive. The news says that a large fire has broken out in a huge chemical plant.

definition_vi: to cause to happen
examples_vi: John brought about the accident because of his carelessness. The heavy rains we have each spring bring about serious flooding.

definition_vi: to return a bought or borrowed item
examples_vi: Ma'am, our store policy is that you can bring back the dress as long as you have your sales receipt. You can borrow my car if you promise to bring it back by six o'clock. I have to take this book back to the library today.

definition_vi: to show or introduce
examples_vi: Most automobile companies bring out new models each year. My mother brought some snacks out for my friends and me to have.

definition_vi: to rear, to raise from childhood
examples_vi: Parents should bring up their children to be responsible members of society. Sarah wanted to bring the scheduling problem up at the club meeting, but finally she decided against doing so. One of the students brought up an interesting point related to the subject in our textbook.

definition_vi: to review something in order to refresh one's memory
examples_vi: Before I traveled to Mexico, I brushed up on my Spanish
I haven't practiced it since high school. In order to take that advanced mathematics class, Sidney will have to brush up on his algebra.

definition_vi: to increase slowly, to make stronger gradually
examples_vi: They built up their savings account so that they could buy a new house. The professional athlete exercises regularly to build her strength up.

definition_vi: to burn slowly, but completely
examples_vi: There was a large amount of wax on the table where the candles had burned down. The fire spread so quickly that the firefighters could not prevent the whole block of buildings from burning down.

definition_vi: to stop functioning because of overuse; to make tired from too much work
examples_vi: This light bulb has burned out. Could you get another one? Studying all day for my final exams has really burned me out.

definition_vi: to destroy completely by fire
examples_vi: She didn't want anyone to see the letter, so she burned it up and threw the ashes away. It really burns me up that he borrowed my car without asking me first. Mike got ticked off that his friends never offered to help him move to his new apartment. He had to do everything himself.

definition_vi: to depart quickly ; to act suddenly
examples_vi: Faye and Debbie were so angry at each other that one of them burst out the front door of the house and the other stormed out the back door. It was so funny to see a little baby in the audience burst out crying when the choir group burst out singing at the start of the recital.

definition_vi: to purchase a business or company
examples_vi: Larger companies often buy out smaller companies that are having financial difficulties. Mr. Lee has been trying for some time to buy his partner out so that he can control the company by himself.

definition_vi: to buy the complete stock of
examples_vi: Before the hurricane struck, residents bought up all the food and water in local stores. The government plans to buy up all surplus grain in order to stabilize the price.

definition_vi: to require; to request, to urge
examples_vi: This cake recipe calls for some baking soda, but we don't have any. The members of Congress called for new laws to regulate the banking industry.

definition_vi: to stop working for the rest of the day/night
examples_vi: Herb tried to repair his car engine all morning before he called it a day and went fishing. We've been working hard on this project all evening
let's call it a night.

definition_vi: to cancel
examples_vi: The referee called off the soccer game because of the darkness. The president called the meeting off because she had to leave town.

definition_vi: to ask for a response from; to visit
examples_vi: Jose didn't know the answer when the teacher called on him. Last night several friends called on us at our home. Why don't we drop in on Sally a little later?

definition_vi: to telephone
examples_vi: I forgot to call up Mr. Jones yesterday. I'd better call him now. Call me up tomorrow, Jane. We'll arrange a time to have lunch together. I promise to give you a call as soon as I arrive in New York.

definition_vi: to continue as before; to conduct, to engage in; to behave in an immature manner
examples_vi: Even in the face of disaster, the inhabitants carried on as though nothing had happened. The business associates decided to carry on their discussion in the hotel bar instead of the conference room. I can't believe that John carried on so much just because his dog died. He looked depressed and cried for weeks after it happened.

definition_vi: to accomplish, to execute
examples_vi: It's easy to write down a plan for losing weight, but much harder to carry it out. Charles promised to go through with his plan to enroll in graduate school and get an advanced degree.

definition_vi: to become sick with a cold of the nose or throat
examples_vi: If you go out in the rain, you will surely catch cold. How did she ever catch cold in such warm weather?

definition_vi: to begin to burn
examples_vi: Don't stand too close to the gas stove. Your clothes may catch fire. No one seems to know how the old building caught fire.

definition_vi: to become popular or widespread; to understand, to appreciate a joke
examples_vi: Fashions of the past often catch on again among young people. When the teacher speaks quickly like that, can you catch on easily? His joke was very funny at the time, but when I told it to others later, nobody seemed to catch on. I had to tell the joke again before anyone could catch on to it.

definition_vi: to work with the purpose of fulfilling a requirement or being equal to others
examples_vi: The student was absent from class so long that it took her a long time to catch up. If you are not equal to others, first you have to catch up with them before you can keep up with them.

word: to change one's (my, his, your, etc. ) mind
definition_vi: to alter one's decision or opinion
examples_vi: We have changed our minds and are going to Canada instead of California this summer. Matthew has changed his mind several times about buying a new car.

definition_vi: to register at a hotel or motel; to leave or deposit for transporting or safekeeping
examples_vi: Courtney arrived in town at mid-day and promptly checked in at the Plaza Hotel. The hotel permitted an early check-in time. There were dozens of people at the airline counters waiting to check their bags in for their flights.

definition_vi: to pay the bill at a hotel or motel and then leave; to investigate, to examine
examples_vi: The latest you should check out of the hotel is 12 noon. However, in your case, we can set a special check-out time of 2:00 P.M. The police received a call from someone claiming to have witnessed a murder. The police sent two detectives to check the call out right away.

definition_vi: to examine with the purpose of determining condition
examples_vi: The government always checks up on the background of employees who are hired for sensitive military projects. The doctor wants me to have a thorough medical checkup as part of a preventive medicine program.

definition_vi: to make happier, to feel less sad
examples_vi: We all tried to cheer up the little boy when he started to cry. After the death of Deanne's husband, it was difficult to cheer her up at all.

definition_vi: to empty, to tidy by removing
examples_vi: It's time for you to clean out your closet so that you can store more things in there. A burglar entered my apartment while I was gone and cleaned me out. He took over $200 in cash and jewelry. Thousands of shoppers cleaned out the store that had gone bankrupt and was selling all its remaining products at very reduced prices.

definition_vi: to make understandable ; to become sunny
examples_vi: The teacher tried to clear up our confusion about the meaning of the difficult paragraph in the reading. It's rather cloudy this morning. Do you think that it will clear up later?

definition_vi: to happen
examples_vi: I didn't find any explanation in the newspaper about how the political coup came about. The flood came about as a result of the heavy winter rains.

definition_vi: to meet or find unexpectedly
examples_vi: While Cheryl was cleaning the attic, she came across some very old coins. It took her by surprise to run across something like that. Jeff's boss comes across as a tough, unpleasant person, but actually Jeff says that he is a good employer. Some people come off quite differently than they really are.

definition_vi: to originate from
examples_vi: What country in South America does she come from? She comes from Peru. I just learned that he really comes from Florida, not Texas. Where did this package come from? The mail carrier brought it.

definition_vi: to regain consciousness; to equal, to amount to
examples_vi: At first they thought that the man was dead, but soon he came to. The bill for groceries at the supermarket came to fifty dollars.

definition_vi: to end, to stop
examples_vi: The meeting finally came to an end at ten o'clock in the evening. Even though my friend seemed to enjoy the movie, I thought that it would never come to an end.

definition_vi: to become reality, to prove to be correct
examples_vi: The weatherman's forecast for today's weather certainly came true. Everything that the economists predicted about the increased cost of living has come true.

definition_vi: to avoid one's responsibility, to quit
examples_vi: Evelyn had agreed to help us with arrangements for the party, but she copped out at the last minute. I can't believe that Cindy offered such an explanation for failing to show up. What a poor copout!

definition_vi: to trust someone in time of need
examples_vi: I can count on my parents to help me in an emergency. Don't depend on Frank to lend you any money
he doesn't have any.

definition_vi: to take someone's place temporarily, to substitute for; to protect someone by lying or deceiving
examples_vi: Go ahead and take your coffee break. I'll cover for you until you return. The criminal made his wife cover for him when the police asked if the man had been home all day. She swore that he had been there.

definition_vi: to be extensive, to discuss much material
examples_vi: That national commission's report on urban ghettos covers a lot of ground. Many of the recommendations are too costly to implement. In his first lecture on Greek philosophers, I thought that our professor covered too little ground.

definition_vi: to conceal, to hide
examples_vi: The office worker tried to cover up his crimes, but everyone knew that he had been stealing office supplies all along. The political coverup of the bribery scandal failed and was reported by all the major media.

definition_vi: to cancel by marking with a horizontal line
examples_vi: The teacher crossed out several incorrect words in Tanya's composition. I crossed the last line out of my letter because it had the wrong tone to it.

definition_vi: to economize, to save money
examples_vi: Most students live on limited budgets and have to cut corners whenever possible. The Livingstons have nine children, so it is essential that they cut corners at all times.

definition_vi: to reduce, to lessen
examples_vi: In order to lose weight, you have to cut down on your intake of sugar. The doctor told me to cut back on exercise until my back injury heals.

definition_vi: to shorten by cutting the ends
examples_vi: The rope was two feet longer than we needed, so we cut off the extra length. The operator cut our long-distance phone conversation off after two minutes.

definition_vi: to remove by cutting
examples_vi: The child likes to cut out pictures from the newspaper and to paste them in a notebook. He kept bothering her, so finally she told him to cut it out. However, he wouldn't knock it off until her larger brother appeared.

definition_vi: to make shorter, to interrupt
examples_vi: The moderator asked the speaker to cut short his talk because there wasn't much time remaining for questions from the audience. We were very unfortunate when we received bad news from home that forced us to cut our trip short.

definition_vi: to decrease, to lessen in strength
examples_vi: The hurricane became a less serious tropical storm when its winds died down. We let the fire in the fireplace die down and enjoyed watching the embers as they glowed in the dark.

definition_vi: not to exist anymore; to be in the process of disappearing
examples_vi: Scientists still are not sure exactly why the dinosaurs died out. That strange, new style of dancing is slowly dying out.

definition_vi: to distribute in large quantity
examples_vi: Mary's mom dished out two or three scoops of ice cream for each child at the birthday party. Larry can't seem to take any criticism of his actions but he certainly likes to dish it out.

definition_vi: to revise, to do again
examples_vi: You'd better do the letter over because it is written so poorly. Jose made so many mistakes in his homework that the teacher made him do it over.

definition_vi: survive or exist without something
examples_vi: With prices so high now, I'll have to do without a new suit this year. As a traveling salesperson, Monica can't do without a car. It's a shame that so many poor people in the world have to go without basic necessities of life such as nutritious food and suitable shelter.

definition_vi: to determine to be unacceptable, to refuse to consider
examples_vi: I don't mind helping him with his homework, but I draw the line at writing a term paper for him. The conference organizers tried to accommodate the needs of the various interest groups, but they drew the line at extending the conference by two days.

definition_vi: to create by drawing, such as a map
examples_vi: Max asked me to draw up a map to the party so that he wouldn't get lost. Our lawyer agreed to draw the contract up as soon as possible.

definition_vi: to wear formal clothes, to dress very nicely
examples_vi: We should definitely dress up to go to the theater. You don't have to dress up for Mike's party.

definition_vi: to fall asleep; to take to a certain location
examples_vi: My mother dropped off during the boring television show

her head was nodding up and down. I don't mind dropping you off at the store on my way to work. Business has been dropping off rapidly recently, but fortunately it hasn't been falling off as quickly as for our competitors.

definition_vi: to stop attending; to withdraw from
examples_vi: Some students drop out of secondary school early in order to get jobs. However, such dropouts often regret their decision later in life. Two more baseball teams have dropped out of the youth league due to a lack of players.

definition_vi: to write a note to someone
examples_vi: As soon as I get to Florida, I'll drop you a line and tell you about my new job. If you have time, drop me a line now and then while you're traveling.

definition_vi: to lose, or cause to lose, moisture gradually
examples_vi: Martha hung the towel outside on the clothesline in order to dry it out. Some people go to alcohol recovery centers in order to dry out.

definition_vi: to lose, or cause to lose, all moisture ; to be depleted
examples_vi: Every summer the extreme heat in this valley dries the stream up. All funds for the project dried up when the local government faced a budget crisis.

definition_vi: to eat at home/to eat in a restaurant
examples_vi: I feel too tired to go out for dinner. Let's eat in again tonight. When you eat out, what restaurant do you generally go to?

definition_vi: to diminish gradually in time or distance
examples_vi: The memory of that unpleasant experience has slowly faded away. The music of the band gradually faded away as the parade passed down the street.

definition_vi: to lag, to fail to keep up
examples_vi: Eve fell behind in her studies and finally had to drop out of school. If you get behind in your car payments, the finance company may repossess it from you.

definition_vi: to fall in love quickly; to be fooled or tricked by
examples_vi: Samantha and Derek never expected to fall for each other like they did, but they got married within two weeks of having met. The Masons wanted to believe their son, but unfortunately they had fallen for his lies too many times to be deceived once again.

definition_vi: to begin to love
examples_vi: Ben and Sal fell in love in high school, and got married after graduation. Have you ever fallen in love at first sight?

definition_vi: to fail to materialize, not to succeed
examples_vi: Our plan to travel to Europe last summer fell through when we were unable to save up enough money. Felix made plans to have a party for everyone in his office, but they fell through at the last moment.

definition_vi: to have the desire to, to want to consider
examples_vi: I don't feel like studying tonight. Let's go to a basketball game. I feel like taking a long walk. Would you like to go with me?

definition_vi: to pity, to feel compassion for
examples_vi: Don't you feel sorry for someone who has to work the night shift? I helped drive Pierre around when he broke his foot because I took pity on him.

definition_vi: to solve, to find a solution
examples_vi: How long did it take you to figure out the answer to the math problem? I was never able to figure it out.

definition_vi: to write answers in
examples_vi: You should be careful to fill in the blanks on the registration form correctly. Barry was absent from the meeting, so I'd better fill him in. Has anyone filled the boss in on the latest public relations disaster?

definition_vi: to complete a form
examples_vi: Every prospective employee must fill out an application by giving name, address, previous jobs, etc. The teenager had some trouble filling the forms out by himself, so his mother helped him.

definition_vi: to inform, to give background information to
examples_vi: Could you fill me in on what is going to be discussed at tomorrow's meeting? Not having been to the convention, my associate asked me to clue him in on the proceedings.

definition_vi: to criticize, to complain about something
examples_vi: It is very easy to find fault with the work of others, but more difficult to accept criticism of one's own work. Mrs. Johnson is always finding fault with her children, but they really try to please their mother.

definition_vi: get information about, to determine
examples_vi: Will you please try to find out what time the airplane arrives? I'll call right now to find it out.

definition_vi: to repair or put back in good condition
examples_vi: Instead of buying an expensive new home, we decided to buy an older home and fix it up ourselves. Since my visiting friend didn't have a date for dinner, I fixed her up with a male friend of mine. They got along very well together.

definition_vi: to waste time ; to joke, not to be serious
examples_vi: The teacher got angry because her students were fooling around and couldn't finish their work before the end of class. Sometimes I wish that Pat would stop fooling around so much and talk about something more interesting to others.

definition_vi: to make progress; to manage to live in a certain state of health
examples_vi: Juan is getting along very well in his English studies. How is Mr. Richards getting along after his long illness?

definition_vi: to associate or work well with; to succeed or manage in doing
examples_vi: Terry isn't getting along with her new roommate
they argue constantly. How are you getting on with your studies?

word: to get a rise out of
definition_vi: to provoke a response from
examples_vi: You can kid me all day about my mistake, but you won't get a rise out of me. I got a rise out of Marvin when I teased him about his weight. Marvin weighs over two-hundred pounds.

definition_vi: to get free, to escape
examples_vi: We always try to get away from the noise and heat of the city for a month or two each summer. No one knows how the suspected criminal got away from the police.

definition_vi: to avoid punishment for
examples_vi: Jonathan tries to get away with coming late to work almost every day
someday he'll suffer the consequences. Terence can't continue to put his friends down like that and expect to get away with it forever.

definition_vi: to return
examples_vi: Mr. Harris got back from his business trip to Chicago this morning. Could you get the children back home by five o'clock?

definition_vi: to become better, worse, etc.
examples_vi: Heather has been sick for a month, but now she is getting better. This medicine isn't helping me. Instead of getting better, I'm getting worse.

definition_vi: to become unable or afraid to do something
examples_vi: Karl was supposed to marry Elaine this weekend, but at the last moment he got cold feet. Only one of the rock climbers got cold feet when the group reached the base of the hundred-meter cliff.

definition_vi: to seek revenge, to retaliate
examples_vi: Bill has had it in for his boss for a long time. He told me he's planning to get even with his boss by giving some company secrets to a competitor. I want to get even with Steve for beating me so badly in tennis last time. The scores were 6-1 and 6-2.

definition_vi: to enter or to board a vehicle
examples_vi: It's easiest to get in the car from the driver's side. The door on the other side doesn't work well. I always get on the bus to work at 34th Street.

definition_vi: to communicate with, to contact
examples_vi: You can get in touch with him by calling the Burma Hotel. I've been trying all morning to get in touch with Miss Peters, but her phone is always busy.

definition_vi: to become lost; to go away in order not to bother
examples_vi: While driving in Boston, we got lost and drove many miles in the wrong direction. Todd kept bothering me while I was studying, so I told him to get lost. Lisa joked that she wanted her sister to get lost forever.

definition_vi: to express one's true feelings
examples_vi: Ellen felt a lot better when she finally talked to a counselor and got the problem off her chest. Faye hasn't shared her concern about her marriage with her husband yet. I think that she should get it off her chest soon.

definition_vi: to annoy or disturb
examples_vi: Laura loves to talk to anyone. Sometimes her chatter really gets on my nerves. Jack asked his neighbor to turn down the stereo because it was bugging him and he couldn't concentrate.

definition_vi: to restore one's financial security, to resolve a difficult financial obligation
examples_vi: After years of struggling to get ahead, the young couple finally got out from under their debts. The ailing company, succeeding in obtaining the necessary cash, was able to get out from under its financial burdens.

definition_vi: to disobey or ignore normal procedures or rules
examples_vi: When a child gets out of line in that teacher's class, she uses the old-fashioned method of making the child sit in the corner of the room. Any employee who steps out of line by coming to work in an unacceptable condition will be fired.

word: to get out of/to get off
definition_vi: to leave or to descend from a vehicle
examples_vi: Why don't we stop and get out of the car for a while? Helen got off the train at the 42nd Street terminal.

definition_vi: to recover from an illness; to accept a loss or sorrow
examples_vi: It took me over a month to get over my cold, but I'm finally well now. It seems that Mr. Mason will never get over the death of his wife.

definition_vi: to eliminate, to remove; to discard, to throw away
examples_vi: Jerry tried hard to get rid of the stain on his shirt, but he never succeeded. The stain was so bad that Jerry finally had to get rid of his shirt.

word: to get sick (well, tired, busy, wet, etc. )
definition_vi: to become sick, well, tired, busy, wet, etc.
examples_vi: Gerald got sick last week and has been in bed since that time. Every afternoon I get very hungry, so I eat a snack.

definition_vi: to win or defeat by gaining an advantage over someone
examples_vi: Jim doesn't seem very athletic at tennis, but if you're not careful, he'll get the better of you. Lynn gets frustrated when Bruce gets the better of her in arguments. No matter what she says, he always has a clever response.

word: to get through doing something, to get through with something
definition_vi: to finish, to complete
examples_vi: I didn't get through studying last night until almost eleven o'clock. At what time does your wife get through with work every day?

definition_vi: to communicate with, to make someone understand
examples_vi: Some of the students in my reading class understand English so poorly that it is difficult to get through to them. The doctors have never succeeded in breaking through to Mr. Ames, who is a silent and secretive patient.

definition_vi: to be able to do something special; to arrive at a place, such as home, work, etc.
examples_vi: The children got to stay up late and watch a good movie for the family. I missed the bus and couldn't get to the office until ten o'clock. When are you planning to get home tonight?

definition_vi: to arise, to rise from a bed; to make someone arise
examples_vi: Carla gets up at seven o'clock every morning. At what time should we get the children up tomorrow?

definition_vi: to become used to, to become adjusted to
examples_vi: It took Yoshiko a long time to get used to the food that her American host family served her. Mark can't seem to get used to wearing contact lenses
recently he's been wearing his glasses a lot.

definition_vi: to bear a human being or animal
examples_vi: Jane's mother has just given birth to twin girls. The zoo's Siberian tiger just gave birth to a baby cub.

definition_vi: to surrender, to stop resisting
examples_vi: Completely surrounded by our soldiers, the enemy finally gave in. Management gave in to the strikers' demands and agreed to a shortened work week.

definition_vi: to release, to produce
examples_vi: When water boils, it gives off steam. The flowers in this garden give off a strange odor.

definition_vi: to distribute; to become exhausted or depleted
examples_vi: An usher stood at the door of the theater giving out programs. I couldn't finish the ten-mile race because my energy gave out. Jeff plans to stay in Las Vegas and gamble until his money runs out.

definition_vi: to clap one's hands in applause, to applaud
examples_vi: After the talented new vocalist had sung her number, the audience gave her a big hand. Should we give a big hand to each beauty contestant is as she is introduced, or should we wait until all the introductions are finished?

definition_vi: to provide a person with another opportunity or chance
examples_vi: The driver pleaded with the police officer to give him a break and not issue him a ticket for speeding. When the students heard how much homework the teacher wanted them to do over the holiday, they begged, "Give us a break, Professor Doyle!" Oh, Jim, give me a break! That's a terrible excuse for being late.

definition_vi: to assist, to aid, to help
examples_vi: Would you give me a hand lifting this heavy box? When Terry's car broke down at night on the highway, no one would stop to lend her a hand.

definition_vi: to stop trying; to stop a bad habit
examples_vi: I'm sure that you can accomplish this task. Don't give up yet! If you give up smoking now, you can certainly live a longer life. The soldiers gave themselves up in the face of stronger enemy forces.

definition_vi: to be sufficient or adequate for everyone present; to circulate, to move from place to place
examples_vi: We thought that we had bought enough food and drink for the party, but actually there wasn't enough to go around. There's a bad strain of influenza going around right now. Have you gotten your flu shots yet? Mike has been going around telling people that he was accepted to Harvard University. Do you believe him?

definition_vi: to be sold at a certain price; to seek or strive for
examples_vi: This dress probably goes for about $50, don't you think? Peter was going for first place in the swim meet, but he wasn't able to do better than third place.

definition_vi: to have as an interest, such as a sport or hobby
examples_vi: Hal goes in for tennis while his wife goes in for painting and sculpture. What sports are you into? I don't have any time to get into sports.

definition_vi: to explode, to sound as an alarm; to leave suddenly without explanation
examples_vi: The accident happened when a box of firecrackers went off accidentally. For what time did you set the alarm clock to go off tomorrow morning? Vince went off without saying good-bye to anybody
I hope he wasn't angry.

word: to go off the deep end
definition_vi: to get very angry and do something hastily
examples_vi: Just because you had a serious argument with your supervisor, you didn't have to go off the deep end and resign, did you? When Dan's wife demanded a divorce, he went off the deep end again. This time he was shouting so that the whole neighborhood could hear.

definition_vi: to waste time, to be idle
examples_vi: Some of the workers in our office always goof off when the boss is out. On Saturday afternoons, I like to go to a movie or just goof off at home.

definition_vi: to perform badly, to make a mistake
examples_vi: I really goofed up on the exam today
did you mess up, too? Karen slipped up when she forgot to deposit money into her checking account.

definition_vi: to happen; to resume, to continue
examples_vi: Many people gathered near the accident to see what was going on. I didn't mean to interrupt you. Please go on. The speaker kept on talking even though most of the audience had left.

definition_vi: to stop functioning; to stop burning; to leave home or work
examples_vi: The lights went out all over the city because of an electrical problem. The campers didn't have to put out the fire because it went out by itself. Gary isn't here right now
he went out to the store for a moment. I have to step out of the office briefly to pick up a newspaper.

definition_vi: to be appreciated or accepted
examples_vi: The teacher's organized lessons always go over well with her students. The comedian's jokes weren't going over well
the audience wasn't laughing much at all. I think that the comedian should go over his material more carefully before each act.

definition_vi: to undergo, to experience; to consume, to use
examples_vi: I can't believe what she went through to get that job. She had four interviews with the hiring committee in one week! Frank said that they had gone through all the toilet paper in the house, but Steve couldn't believe that they had used it all up.

definition_vi: to send a request through the normal way
examples_vi: If you go through proper channels in this company, it's sometimes impossible to get anything done quickly. The police told the important civic leader that even she had to go through channels in reporting the burglary of her house.

definition_vi: to do something with enthusiasm and thoroughness
examples_vi: Our interior decorator really went to town in remodeling our living room. I'm afraid to ask how much it's going to cost. Charlie really went to town on his research project. He consulted over forty reference works and wrote a ninety-page report.

definition_vi: to increase ; to be constructed, to be erected
examples_vi: Economists are predicting that consumer prices are going up. Inflation always has a tendency to drive up the cost of products. A new office is going up in the downtown area. A major construction company is putting it up.

definition_vi: to approach
examples_vi: After the lecture, several people in the audience went up to the speaker to congratulate her. The little girl came up to me and shook my hand as if she had known me for years. Bill's friend didn't want to admit that they had gotten lost, but finally he agreed to drive up to a gas station and inquire about the correct route.

definition_vi: to match, to compare well in color or design; to date, to accompany
examples_vi: That striped shirt goes well with the gray pants, but the pants go poorly with those leather shoes. Eda went with Richard for about six months, but now she is going out with a new boyfriend.

definition_vi: to be known without the need to mention
examples_vi: It goes without saying that you shouldn't drive quickly in bad weather. That he will gain weight if he continues to eat and drink so much goes without saying.

definition_vi: to fail, to result badly
examples_vi: Something went wrong with the engine, so we had to have the car towed to a garage. Shawn should have been here over an hour ago
I'm certain that something went wrong.

definition_vi: to outgrow, to become too old for, to be a result of
examples_vi: He still bites his nails now and then, but soon he'll grow out of the habit. The need for the salary committee grew out of worker dissatisfaction with the pay scale.

definition_vi: to submit or deliver something that is due
examples_vi: Every student has to hand in an original composition each week of the semester. All the salespeople hand their weekly reports in on Friday.

definition_vi: to place clothes on a hook or hanger
examples_vi: Would you like me to hang up your coat for you in the closet? The operator told me to hang the phone up and call the number again.

definition_vi: to enjoy oneself
examples_vi: We all had a good time at the class reunion last night. Did you have a good time at the park? I really enjoyed it.

definition_vi: to share involvement in
examples_vi: The new vice-president was promised that she would have a voice in developing the company's international expansion. The students are trying to have a voice in college affairs by gaining representation on administrative committees.

definition_vi: to be considering, to be thinking
examples_vi: I don't want to see a movie now. I have in mind going to the park. It's up to you what we eat tonight. Do you have anything in mind?

definition_vi: to want revenge on, to feel hostile towards
examples_vi: Martina expects to lose her job because her boss has had it in for her for a long time. The teacher has held a grudge against Al ever since the time that he insulted her in front of the class.

definition_vi: to quarrel with, to confront
examples_vi: I am going to have it out with Jack about all the times that he has told us lies. Ben had it out with his roommate about coming back home so late and making a lot of noise.

definition_vi: to be wearing
examples_vi: How do you like the hat which Grace has on today? When Sally came into the room, I had nothing on except my shorts.

word: to have one's heart set on
definition_vi: to desire greatly, to be determined to
examples_vi: She has her heart set on taking a trip abroad. She's been thinking about it for months. Todd has his heart set on going to medical school and becoming a doctor.

definition_vi: to arrange matters the way one wants
examples_vi: My brother always wants to have his way, but this time our parents said that we could do what I wanted. If Sheila doesn't get her way, she becomes very angry.

definition_vi: to have free time, not to have to work
examples_vi: Every morning the company workers have time off for a coffee break. Several workers took the afternoon off to go to a baseball game.

definition_vi: to have some connection with or relationship to
examples_vi: Ralph insisted that he had nothing to do with breaking the window. What does your suggestion have to do with our problem?

definition_vi: to receive news or information from
examples_vi: I don't hear from my brother very often since he moved to Chicago. Have you heard from the company about that new job?

definition_vi: to know about, to be familiar with; to consider
examples_vi: When I asked for directions to Mill Street, the police officer said that she had never heard of it. Byron strongly disagreed with my request by saying, "I won't hear of it!"

definition_vi: to delay, or to be delayed, in occurring
examples_vi: If the rain holds off for a few more days, they can finish planting the rest of the crop. The judge agreed to hold off making a decision until new evidence could be introduced into court.

definition_vi: to grasp tightly or firmly; to wait, to be patient
examples_vi: The little girl held on to her mother's hand and refused to let go as they walked through the large crowd of people. (on the telephone) Could you please hold on a moment while I get a pencil and paper? Come on, Mike, hold on. I can't get ready so quickly.

definition_vi: to endure, to be sufficient; to survive by resisting; to persist in one's efforts
examples_vi: If our supply of food and water holds out, we plan to camp here for another week. However, whenever it gives out, we'll have to leave. That nation's troops cannot hold out much longer against the superior forces of the enemy. The valuable football player held out for more money before signing a new contract with his team.

definition_vi: to extend, to keep for a longer time
examples_vi: They are going to hold over that movie for another week because so many people are coming to see it. Let's hold discussion of this problem over until our next meeting.

definition_vi: not to move
examples_vi: Please hold still while I adjust your tie. If you don't hold that camera still, you'll get a blurred picture.

definition_vi: to delay, to make late ; to remain high in quality
examples_vi: A big accident held up traffic on the highway for several hours. Deidre is amazed at how well her car has held up over the years.

definition_vi: to remind constantly, to nag
examples_vi: Lynn always has to keep after her children about cleaning up their rooms and doing chores around the house. Lon is so forgetful that it's necessary to keep after him about every little thing.

definition_vi: to stay at a distance
examples_vi: Please be sure to keep the children away from the street! The signs on the burned-out house said, "Keep Away! Danger Zone." It's important for your health to stay away from dangerous drugs.

definition_vi: to remember, not to forget
examples_vi: Please keep in mind that you promised to call Stan around noon. I didn't know that Paula doesn't like vegetables. We should bear that in mind next time we invite her for dinner.

definition_vi: to maintain contact with
examples_vi: You can telephone me every few days, and in that way we can keep in touch with each other. He promised to stay in touch with us while he was abroad. However, we were very disappointed that he never did get in touch with us.

definition_vi: to hope to have good results, to hope that nothing bad will happen
examples_vi: Let's keep our fingers crossed that we got passing grades on that college entrance exam. Jerry kept his fingers crossed that the good weather would hold up for the picnic he was planning for the coming weekend.

definition_vi: to remain calm during an emergency
examples_vi: When the heater caused a fire, Gloria kept her head and phoned for assistance right away
otherwise, the whole house might have burned down. When the boat starting sinking in heavy seas, the crew members kept their heads and led the passengers to the lifeboats.

definition_vi: to fulfill a promise, to be responsible
examples_vi: Suzanne kept her word to me not to let on to others that I intend to step down next month. Thomas always intends to keep his word, but invariably the end result is that he breaks his word. He just isn't capable of being a responsible person.

definition_vi: not to enter, not allow to enter
examples_vi: There was a large sign outside the door that said, "Danger! Keep out!" I've told you to keep the dog out of the house.

definition_vi: to operate accurately
examples_vi: Although this is a cheap watch, it keeps good time. The old clock keeps perfect time
it's never fast or slow.

definition_vi: to keep or maintain a record of; to remember the location of
examples_vi: Steve keeps track of all the long-distance telephone calls related to his business that he makes from his home. With seven small children, how do the Wilsons keep track of all of them?

definition_vi: to prevent from sleeping
examples_vi: Could you please turn down the TV volume? You're keeping up the children. If we can keep up this speed, we should arrive there in about two hours. James is so proud of his daughter for getting mostly A's in school. He's certain that she can keep up the good work. The Federal Reserve Bank hopes to keep the value of the dollar up at least through the rest of the year.

definition_vi: to maintain the same speed or rate as
examples_vi: Frieda works so fast that no one in the office can keep up with her. You'll have to walk more slowly. I can't keep up with you.

definition_vi: to have current knowledge of; to understand as an explanation
examples_vi: Evan keeps up with world affairs by reading a news magazine each week. I understand a lot of the Spanish language, but I can't keep up with the fast conversation in this Mexican film.

definition_vi: to discuss informally
examples_vi: At first my friends were reluctant to consider my suggestion, but they finally were willing to kick it around for a while. Herb thought that we should kick around the idea of establishing a special fund for supporting needy members of the club.

definition_vi: to stop a bad habit
examples_vi: Once a child becomes accustomed to chewing his nails, it's difficult to kick the habit. The doctor advised the heavy cigarette smoker that her heart had become damaged and that she should kick the habit right away.

definition_vi: to work very hard to do something
examples_vi: She really knocked herself out trying to pass that difficult class. Don't knock yourself out during practice. Save your strength for the competition later.

definition_vi: to make unconscious
examples_vi: The prizefighter knocked out his opponent with one punch in the first five seconds of the first round. It was the fastest knockout in boxing history. Linda's beautiful appearance and slender figure really knock me out. Isn't she a real knockout tonight?

definition_vi: to recognize
examples_vi: I have never met our new neighbors
I simply know them by sight. The woman said that she would know the thief by sight if she ever saw him again.

definition_vi: to recover safely from an unpleasant or dangerous situation
examples_vi: After a series of personal and professional difficulties, it's amazing that George has landed on his feet so quickly. Some young adults get into so much trouble at school that they are never able to land on their feet again. They drop out before graduating.

definition_vi: to abstain from, stop using as a habit; to release or discharge from a job
examples_vi: If you're trying to lose weight, you should lay off sweet things. If business continues to be slow, we will have to lay off some workers. It will be necessary to let the youngest employees go first.

definition_vi: to become familiar with routine procedures at work or school
examples_vi: The job applicant didn't have much previous experience or knowledge, but she seemed intelligent enough to learn the ropes quickly. It took the new schoolteacher a year to learn the ropes regarding administrative and curricular matters.

definition_vi: to delay making a decision on
examples_vi: In making up the job announcement, the firm decided to leave the salary open until a qualified candidate was found. We know that the annual summer camp will be held in August, but let's leave the exact dates open for now.

definition_vi: not to disturb, to stay away from
examples_vi: Leave the baby alone for a while and she may go to sleep. After the cat had scratched Peter twice, he let it alone.

definition_vi: to reveal or tell what you know, to hint
examples_vi: We are going to the movies tonight and we don't want Doris to go. If you see her, make sure not to let on. They asked me not to let on to Ted that we're planning the birthday party
it's supposed to be a big surprise.

definition_vi: to neglect a duty
examples_vi: Terry knew that she should have paid the electric bill on time instead of letting it slide. Now the utility company has turned off her service. When he tried to get a rise out of me by mentioning my failure to receive a promotion at work, I just let it slide.

definition_vi: to slacken, to lessen in intensity; to relax or ease one's effort
examples_vi: If the rain doesn't let up soon, we won't be able to have our picnic. When Jane is working, she never lets up for a moment. Jane should take it easy or she'll get exhausted.

definition_vi: to place oneself in a flat position, to recline
examples_vi: If you are tired, why don't you lie down for an hour or so? The doctor says that Grace must lie down and rest for a short time every afternoon.

definition_vi: to form a line; to arrange to have, to manage to obtain
examples_vi: The moviegoers lined up in front of the theater showing the most popular film of the summer. Rob is going to schedule the famous author to speak at the convention if he can line her up in time.

definition_vi: to spend money freely, to live luxuriously
examples_vi: Kyle and Eric saved up money for two years so that they could travel to Europe and live it up. After receiving a large inheritance from a rich aunt, I was able to live it up for years.

definition_vi: to energize, to make more active
examples_vi: The teacher occasionally took the class on field trips just to liven things up a bit. The animals in the zoo began to liven up when evening came and the temperatures dropped. Many people have to drink coffee every morning just to pick themselves up.

definition_vi: to fulfill
examples_vi: It was clear that the lazy student would never live up to his family's expectations. It surprised us that the car salesperson lived up to all the promises he made.

definition_vi: to watch, to supervise, to protect
examples_vi: Grandma will look after the baby while we go to the lecture. Who is going to take care of your house plants while you are away? I'd appreciate it if you'd keep an eye on my car while I'm in the store.

definition_vi: give one's attention to; to watch
examples_vi: The teacher told us to look at the blackboard and not at our books. I like to walk along a country road at night and look at the stars.

definition_vi: to feel superior to, to think of someone as less important
examples_vi: People who are in positions of power should be careful not to look down on those who work for them. Why does Alma look down on Mario
just because his family is so poor?

definition_vi: to try to find, to search for
examples_vi: He's spent over an hour looking for the pen that he lost. So there you are! We've looked all over for you.

definition_vi: to expect or anticipate with pleasure
examples_vi: We're greatly looking forward to our vacation in Mexico. Margaret never looks forward to going to work.

definition_vi: to investigate, to examine carefully
examples_vi: The police are looking into the matter of the stolen computers. The congressional committee will check into the financial dealings of the government contractor.

definition_vi: to watch as a spectator, to observe
examples_vi: Hundreds of people were looking on as the police and firefighters rescued the passengers in the wrecked train. I stayed with my son at his first soccer practice and looked on as the coach worked with the boys.

definition_vi: to be careful or cautious
examples_vi: "Look out!" Jeffrey cried as his friend almost stepped in a big hole in the ground. Look out for reckless drivers whenever you cross the street. Small children should always watch out for strangers offering candy.

definition_vi: to face, to overlook
examples_vi: We really enjoy our new apartment that looks out on a river. Their rear window looks out on a lovely garden.

definition_vi: to examine, to inspect closely
examples_vi: I want to look my homework over again before I give it to the teacher. The politician went over his speech before the important presentation. You should never sign any legal paper without checking it over first.

definition_vi: to locate information in a directory, dictionary, book, etc.
examples_vi: Ellen suggested that we look up Lee's telephone number in the directory. Students should try to understand the meaning of a new word from context before looking the word up in the dictionary.

definition_vi: to admire, to respect greatly
examples_vi: Children will most certainly look up to their parents if the children are brought up well. Everyone looks up to the director of our department because he is a kind and generous person.

definition_vi: to get excited, angry, or flustered
examples_vi: Despite the boos from some in the audience, the actors on stage never lost their cool. Although the group of skiers were in danger from an apparent avalanche, their ski guide never lost his cool.

definition_vi: not to think clearly, to lose one's self-control
