examples_vi: When Mel saw a dog in the street right in front of his car, he lost his head and drove onto the sidewalk and into a tree. If the politician hadn't gotten stirred up and lost his head, he never would have criticized his opponent unfairly.

definition_vi: to fail at what one used to do well
examples_vi: Milton used to be the best salesman at the car dealership, but recently he seems to have lost his touch. I used to play tennis very well, but today you beat me easily. I must be losing my touch.

definition_vi: to be of importance , to affect
examples_vi: It makes a big difference to me whether he likes the food I serve. Does it make any difference to you where we go for dinner? No, it doesn't make any difference. It makes no difference to Lisa either.

definition_vi: to clarify, to explain
examples_vi: Please make clear that he should never act so impolitely again. The supervisor made it clear to the workers that they had to increase their productivity.

definition_vi: to manage, to cope
examples_vi: Pearl doesn't have a clean blouse so she has to make do with the one she wore yesterday. During difficult economic times, many people have to make do with less.

definition_vi: to become friendly with others
examples_vi: Patricia is a shy girl and doesn't make friends easily. During the cruise Ronald made friends with almost everyone on the ship.

definition_vi: to laugh at, to joke about
examples_vi: They are making fun of Carla's new hair style. Don't you think that it's really strange? Don't make fun of Jose's English. He's doing the best he can.

definition_vi: to succeed
examples_vi: He is a hard worker, and I'm sure that he will make good in that new job. Alma has always made good in everything that she has done.

definition_vi: to travel a sufficient distance at a reasonable speed
examples_vi: On our last trip, it rained the entire time, so we didn't make good time. We made excellent time on our trip to Florida
it only took eighteen hours.

definition_vi: to do, to succeed, to progress
examples_vi: Charlie didn't make out very well on his final examinations. He may have to repeat one or more classes. How did Rachelle make out on her acting audition in Hollywood yesterday?

definition_vi: to read or see clearly
examples_vi: The letter was so poorly handwritten that I couldn't make out many of the words. Harold, please make the check out to Acme Piano Company.

definition_vi: to be sensible or reasonable
examples_vi: It makes sense to wait until a sunny day to visit the park together. That Jimmy ran away from home suddenly doesn't make sense to any of us.

definition_vi: to motivate to behave or act in a certain way
examples_vi: If a salesperson knows what makes a customer tick, he will be able to sell a lot of merchandise. It's been impossible for us to figure out what makes our new boss tick. One moment she seems pleasant and then the next moment she's upset.

definition_vi: to be sure, to ascertain
examples_vi: Please make sure that you turn off the radio before you go out. Could you make certain of the time? I don't want to miss that TV show.

definition_vi: to do the best that one can in a poor situation
examples_vi: If we can't find a larger apartment soon, we'll just have to make the best of it right here. Even though the Martinez family is having financial problems, they make the best of everything by enjoying the simple pleasures of life.

definition_vi: to meet or fulfill a missed obligation at a later time ; to comprise, to be composed of
examples_vi: The teacher allowed several students who missed the exam to make it up during the next class. The little boy made up a bad excuse for wearing his dirty shoes in the house, so his mother punished him. Dee was able to make her face up in half the normal time because she didn't use much makeup. Two separate bodies — the House of Representatives and the Senate — make up the Congress of the United States.

word: to make up one's (my, his, your, etc. ) mind
definition_vi: to reach a decision, to decide finally
examples_vi: Sally is considering several colleges to attend, but she hasn't made up her mind yet. When are you going to make up your mind about your vacation plans?

definition_vi: to resolve differences with
examples_vi: Gundula made up with her roommate after their serious misunderstanding about arrangements for the party. After the bad quarrel the two lovers kissed and made up with each other.

definition_vi: to create a disturbance, usually by complaining
examples_vi: In most companies, an employee who makes waves is not appreciated. The meeting was going smoothly until one of the participants made waves about the newly revised compensation package.

definition_vi: to compromise with someone
examples_vi: Steve wanted $4,500 for his car, and Gwen offered $4,000. They met each other halfway and agreed on $4,250. After a long process of give and take, the owners of the company agreed to meet the workers halfway by providing some additional health benefits but no wage increase.

definition_vi: to be responsible for an office while others are gone
examples_vi: It seems that all of our employees are taking a lunch break at the same time. I wonder who's minding the store. Lynne agreed to mind the store while the others went outside to watch the parade passing by.

definition_vi: to lose an opportunity, to fail in some undertaking
examples_vi: The precious metals market was looking up several months ago, but unfortunately most investors missed the boat. Mr. Vlasic's new business went bankrupt within a short time. He really missed the boat by opening a tanning salon near the beach.

definition_vi: to stir or shake well
examples_vi: You should mix up the ingredients well before you put them in the pan. The teacher's poor explanation really mixed the students up. The students think it's their fault that they are mixed up so often.

definition_vi: to give the same name as another
examples_vi: Helen's parents named Helen after her grandmother. My grandson is named after Calvin Coolidge, the 30th President of the United States.

definition_vi: to distribute ; to lose consciousness
examples_vi: Please help me pass out these test papers
there must be a hundred of them. Alright, students, here are the class handouts for this week. The weather was so hot in the soccer stadium that some of the fans in the stands passed out.

definition_vi: to look at and listen to someone while they are speaking, to concentrate
examples_vi: Please pay attention to me while I'm speaking to you! You'll have to pay more attention in class if you want to get a good grade.

definition_vi: to choose, to select
examples_vi: Ann picked out a good book to give to her brother as a graduation gift. Johnny, if you want me to buy you a toy, then pick one out now.

definition_vi: to lift from the floor, table, etc. , with one's fingers
examples_vi: Harry picked up the newspaper that was on the front doorstep. Could you pick your toy up before someone falls over it?

definition_vi: to pay the cost or bill
examples_vi: The advertising manager is flying to Puerto Rico for a conference, and her firm is picking up the tab. The government picked up the tab for the visiting dignitary. It paid for all of the lodging and meals, as well as transportation, during his stay.

definition_vi: to find guilty of a crime or offense
examples_vi: The prosecuting attorney tried to pin the murder on the victim's husband, but the jury returned a verdict of "not guilty." I wasn't anywhere near the window when it got broken. You can't pin that on me.

definition_vi: to play music that one has heard but never read
examples_vi: That pianist can play most popular music by ear. She never needs to read sheet music. My husband wanted to plan our trip carefully, but I argued that it was more fun if we played it by ear.

definition_vi: to behave so as to gain favor with someone
examples_vi: The other students in the class resent Jim because he plays up to the teacher in order to get better grades. When my children asked me to go shopping for a new video game, I knew why they had been playing up to me all morning.

definition_vi: to show, to indicate, to bring to one's attention
examples_vi: What important buildings did the tour guide point out to you? The teacher pointed out the mistakes in my composition. A friend pointed the famous actor out to me.

definition_vi: to succeed in doing something difficult ; to exit to the side of a highway
examples_vi: The group of investors pulled off a big deal by buying half the stock in that company. I wonder how they pulled it off before the company could prevent it. The motorist pulled off when the police officer turned on the red lights and the siren.

definition_vi: to gather, to collect
examples_vi: The reporter pulled together information from several sources in preparing the newspaper article. Mr. Simpson was so frightened when he heard footsteps behind him on the lonely, dark street that it took several minutes to pull himself together.

definition_vi: to cause to end, to terminate in a definite manner
examples_vi: The dictatorial government put an end to organized opposition in the country by making it illegal to form a political party. It may never be possible to do away with all forms of prejudice and discrimination in the world.

definition_vi: to remove from sight, to put in the proper place
examples_vi: Please put away your papers before you open the test booklet. John put the notepad away in his desk when he was finished with it.

definition_vi: to suppress, to quell
examples_vi: The police arrived just in time to put down the disturbance before it got very serious. Fred tries his best at playing tennis. You shouldn't put him down like that.

definition_vi: to postpone
examples_vi: Many students put off doing their assignments until the last minute. Let's put the party off until next weekend, okay?

definition_vi: to place on oneself
examples_vi: Mary put on her coat and left the room. Put your hat on before you leave the house.

definition_vi: to gain
examples_vi: Bob has put on a lot of weight recently. He must have put at least fifteen pounds on. The Youth Actor's Guild put on a wonderful version of Romeo and Juliet at the globe Theater.

definition_vi: to say or do the wrong thing
examples_vi: Fred really put his foot in his mouth when he called his supervisor by the wrong name. I really put my foot in it when I forgot my girlfriend's birthday and didn't buy her anything. She almost lost her cool.

definition_vi: extinguish, to cause to stop functioning
examples_vi: No smoking is allowed in here. Please put out your cigarette. The fire fighters worked hard to put the brush fire out. Please put out the light before you leave. Okay, I'll put it out.

definition_vi: to mislead by joking or tricking
examples_vi: Don't worry. I wouldn't expect you do all that work by yourself. I'm just putting you on. Jack can't be serious about what he said. He must be putting us on.

definition_vi: to assemble
examples_vi: Todd followed the directions on the box but he couldn't manage to put the bicycle together properly. After the teenager took the broken video game apart and fixed it, he was unable to put it back together again.

definition_vi: to construct, to erect
examples_vi: The construction company is tearing down that old office building in order to put up a new one. Please put your hand up if you have never studied English grammar before.

definition_vi: to tolerate, to accept unwillingly
examples_vi: The employee was fired because his boss could not put up with his mistakes any longer. While I'm studying, I can't put up with any noise or other distractions.

definition_vi: to refuse to consider, to prohibit
examples_vi: Heather ruled out applying to college in Texas because she would rather go to school in Canada. I'd like to watch a good movie on TV tonight, but a ton of homework rules that out.

definition_vi: to leave without permission; to escape
examples_vi: The young couple ran away and got married because their parents wouldn't permit it. That cat is just like a criminal — it runs away from anyone who tries to come near!

definition_vi: to meet someone unexpectedly; to crash or collide into
examples_vi: It was a shock to run into an old friend from high school recently. The drunk driver was slightly injured when he ran into a telephone pole.

definition_vi: to exhaust the supply of, not to have more of
examples_vi: We ran out of gas right in the middle of the main street in town. It's dangerous to run out of water if you are in an isolated area.

definition_vi: to confuse, to scramble
examples_vi: Chris had trouble finding Jane's apartment because the addresses of the buildings screwed him up. Instead of fixing the television set, the technician screwed it up even more.

definition_vi: to give attention or time to
examples_vi: Who is going to see about getting us a larger room for the meeting? I'll see to arranging music for the wedding if you attend to the entertainment.

word: to see eye to eye (on something/with somebody)
definition_vi: to agree, to concur
examples_vi: I'm glad that we see eye to eye on the matter of the conference location. A husband and wife don't always see eye to eye with each other, but a good marriage can survive small disagreements.

definition_vi: to say good-bye upon departure by train, airplane, bus, etc.
examples_vi: We are going to the airport to see Peter off on his trip to Europe. When I left for Cincinnati on a business trip, no one came to the train station to send me off.

definition_vi: to accompany a person out of a house, building, etc.
examples_vi: The Johnsons were certain to see their guests out as each one left the party. Would you please see me out to the car? It's very dark outside.

definition_vi: to sell all items
examples_vi: That store is closing its doors for good and is selling out everything this weekend. If my new business enterprise is successful, I'll sell it out for a few million dollars.

definition_vi: to receive one's just punishment
examples_vi: It serves Jonathan right to be fired from his job. It serves Terence right that none of his friends are willing to help him move to a new apartment.

definition_vi: to be useful, to suit one's needs or requirements
examples_vi: I don't have a screwdriver to open this, but I think that a knife will serve the purpose. Jane prefers working to studying, so it served her purpose to drop out of school and take that job.

definition_vi: to start traveling toward a place
examples_vi: We set out for the top of the mountain at dawn. Unfortunately, as we set off, it started to snow heavily, so we decided to head out again later. The children tried to set out the dishes on the table, but their dad had to help to lay the dishes out properly.

word: to set out to do something
definition_vi: to intend to, to act purposefully to
examples_vi: We set out to paint the house in one day but quickly realized that it would be impossible to do so. Janet set out to compete for the large scholarship grant by writing a good essay.

definition_vi: to exchange greetings by clasping hands
examples_vi: When people meet for the first time, they usually shake hands. The student warmly shook hands with his old professor.

definition_vi: to display one's ability in order to attract attention
examples_vi: Elizabeth is an excellent swimmer, but I don't like the way she shows off in front of everyone. It's very obvious that she enjoys being a showoff. Jacquie showed her large wedding ring off to all her friends.

definition_vi: to appear, to arrive; to be found or located
examples_vi: It really gets on my nerves that Ursula shows up late for every meeting. Willie hopes that the watch he lost last Sunday shows up soon. We've looked everywhere for that book, but it hasn't turned up yet.

definition_vi: to close for a period of time ; to be quiet, to stop talking
examples_vi: During the hurricane, all the store owners shut their shops up. Bob's sister told him to shut up and not say anything more about it. The student got into big trouble for telling his teacher to shut up.

definition_vi: to be seated
examples_vi: We sat down on the park bench and watched the children play. There aren't any more chairs, but you can take a seat on the floor.

definition_vi: to go, or cause to go, more slowly
examples_vi: The car was going so fast that the motorist couldn't slow it down enough to make the sharp curve. You're eating too fast to digest your food well. Slow down! Slow up a bit! You're talking so quickly that I can't catch on well.

definition_vi: to have the possibility of accomplishing something
examples_vi: The New York baseball team stands a good chance of winning the World Series this year. Because John doesn't have any previous work experience, he doesn't stand a chance of getting that job. The woman injured in the serious train accident doesn't stand much chance of surviving.

definition_vi: to represent, to signify; to tolerate
examples_vi: On the American flag, each star stands for one of the fifty states, and each stripe stands for one of the original thirteen colonies of the 1800s. The citizens wouldn't stand for the increase in crime in their city, so they hired more police officers and built another jail.

definition_vi: to be easily visible or noticeable
examples_vi: Her bright red hair makes her stand out from others in the group. Brandon Styles is a tall, distinguished gentleman who sticks out in any crowd.

definition_vi: to rise from a sitting or lying position
examples_vi: When the president entered the room, everyone stood up. Suzy, stop rolling around on the floor
get up now.

definition_vi: to withstand use or wear; to fail to appear for a date or social engagement
examples_vi: My old car has stood up well over the years. I haven't had any major problems at all. Janet was very angry because her new boyfriend stood her up on their second date. She waited over an hour for him before returning home.

definition_vi: to insist on, to demand; to defend, to support
examples_vi: If you don't stand up for your rights in court, the lawyers will try to stick it to you. Frank stood up for his friend, who was being put down by other teenagers nearby.

definition_vi: to remain at home, not to go out
examples_vi: On a rainy day, I like to stay in and read. Young people are able to stay out late at night and get very little sleep.

definition_vi: to remain awake, not to go to bed
examples_vi: I want to stay up tonight and watch a late movie on TV. He stays up every night until after one o'clock, preparing his homework.

definition_vi: to retire or leave a top position, to resign
examples_vi: Next May the principal will step down after thirty-five years of service to the school. The angry shareholders wanted the company president to step down because of the stock scandal.

definition_vi: to become involved or concerned with something; to enter a place for a brief time
examples_vi: When the children started fighting on the play-ground, a teacher had to step in and stop the fight. The supervisor asked one of the employees to step in her office for a moment. Would you step into the hallway so that I can show you the information posted on the bulletin board?

definition_vi: to treat severely, to discipline; to go faster, to work more quickly
examples_vi: Sometimes it's necessary to step on children when they do something dangerous. We're going to be late for the movies. You'd better step on it!

definition_vi: to stay or remain where one is, to wait
examples_vi: Todd had to stick around the house all day until the new furniture was finally delivered in the late afternoon. Why don't you stick around for a while and see if Sarah eventually shows up?

definition_vi: to cheat, to take unfair advantage of
examples_vi: Be careful in doing business with that salesperson. He'll stick it to you at the first opportunity. The car dealership certainly ripped me off when I bought this car. It has caused me trouble constantly. You paid over $400 for that jacket? What a ripoff!

definition_vi: to adhere to
examples_vi: He made a promise to his wife to quit smoking and drinking, and so far he has stuck to it. All organizations expect their employees to stick to established work rules and procedures. If you try hard to stick to your principles, then you'll be able to live up to them.

definition_vi: to point or place upwards
examples_vi: You should put some water on your hair. It's sticking up in the back. A masked thief stuck up a grocery store in the neighborhood last night.

definition_vi: to cause anger
examples_vi: The senseless murder of a small child stirred up the whole neighborhood. The boss is in a bad mood today so don't stir her up with any more customer complaints.

definition_vi: to visit or stop somewhere briefly in order to do something
examples_vi: James had to stop by the registrar's office to submit a transcript request form. Let's stop by the supermarket and pick up a few grocery items.

definition_vi: to use well, to profit from; to use another person's weaknesses to gain what one wants
examples_vi: I took advantage of my neighbor's superior skill at tennis to improve my own ability at the game. Teddy is such a small, weak child that his friends take advantage of him all the time. They take advantage of him by demanding money and making him do things for them.

definition_vi: to resemble a parent or close relative
examples_vi: Which of your parents do you take after the most? Sam looks like his father, but he takes after his mother in personality.

definition_vi: to disassemble, to separate the parts of something
examples_vi: It is much easier to take a watch apart than it is to assemble it. The engine had a serious problem, so the mechanic had to take it apart completely in order to fix it.

definition_vi: to go on a journey, to travel
examples_vi: I'm so busy at work that I have no time to take a trip. During the summer holidays, the Thompsons took a trip to Europe.

word: to take a walk, stroll, hike, etc.
definition_vi: to go for a walk, stroll, hike, etc.
examples_vi: Last evening we took a walk around the park. It's a fine day. Would you like to take a stroll along Mason Boulevard? Let's take a hike up Cowles Mountain this afternoon.

definition_vi: to surprise, to amaze, to astonish
examples_vi: The offer of a high-paying position with another company took me by surprise. The president's announcement that the university was in financial trouble didn't take anyone by surprise.

definition_vi: to remove from an elevated place ; to write what is said, to note
examples_vi: We should take the pictures down from the wall and clean off the dust. The secretary took down everything that was said at the meeting.

definition_vi: to perceive or understand as
examples_vi: Because of his strong, muscular body, I took him for a professional athlete. As it turns out, he doesn't play any professional sports. What do you take me for — a fool? I don't believe what you're saying at all.

definition_vi: not to appreciate fully
examples_vi: John took his wife for granted until once when he was very sick and needed her constant attention for a week. He spoke English so well that I took it for granted he was an American. He took for granted that I wasn't American because I spoke English so poorly!

definition_vi: to grasp, to grip with the hands
examples_vi: You should take hold of the railing as you go down those steep stairs. The blind man took hold of my arm as I led him across the street.

definition_vi: to visit in order to enjoy
examples_vi: We decided to take in Toronto on our trip to Canada, and that is where we took in the most memorable outdoor stage play we have ever seen. Lois lost so much weight that she had her skirts and slacks taken in by her tailor. The fraudulent investment advisor took everyone in with his sincere manner and generous promises. Most investors lost all their money.

definition_vi: to remove
examples_vi: John took off his jacket as he entered the office. Take your sweater off. The room is very warm.

definition_vi: to leave the ground ; to leave, often in a hurry
examples_vi: The plane took off over an hour late. The passengers had to buckle their seatbelts during takeoff. Do you have to take off already? You just arrived an hour ago!

definition_vi: to employ, to hire ; to accept responsibility for, to undertake
examples_vi: That factory is taking a lot of new employees on for its new production line. Would you be willing to take on the task of organizing the next company picnic?

word: to take one's (my, his, your, etc. ) time
definition_vi: to do without rush, not to hurry
examples_vi: There's no need to hurry doing those exercises. Take your time. William never works rapidly. He always takes his time in everything that he does.

definition_vi: to remove, to extract
examples_vi: Students, take out your books and open them to page twelve. Did you take Sue out last night? No, she couldn't go out with me.

definition_vi: to assume control or responsibility for
examples_vi: That large investment company specializes in taking over smaller businesses that are in financial trouble. Most students didn't do well on the important test, so the instructor let them take it over. Little Mikey didn't have much chance to hit the baseball during practice, so the coach let him take his turn over.

definition_vi: to work carefully and conscientiously
examples_vi: She takes pains to do everything well
she's our best employee. He took great pains with his last assignment because he needed to get an excellent grade to pass the class.

definition_vi: to be involved in, to participate in
examples_vi: Martin was sick and could not take part in the meeting yesterday. I didn't want to be in on their argument, so I remained silent.

definition_vi: to occur, to happen according to plan
examples_vi: The regular meetings of the committee take place in Constitution Hall. I thought that the celebration was taking place at John's house.

word: to take somebody at one's word
definition_vi: to accept what one says as true, to believe
examples_vi: When he offered to be responsible for the fund raiser, I took him at his word. Now he's saying that he's not available to do it. You should be careful about taking her at her word. She's been known to say one thing but to do another.

definition_vi: to consider a fact while evaluating a situation
examples_vi: The judge took the prisoner's young age into account before sentencing him to three months in jail. Educators should take into account the cultural backgrounds of students when planning a school curriculum.

word: to take the bull by the horns
definition_vi: to handle a difficult situation with determination
examples_vi: After three years of faithful service, Jake decided to take the bull by the horns and ask his boss for a raise. Vic has been engaged to Laura for a long time now, and I know that he loves her. He should take the bull by the horns and ask her to marry him.

definition_vi: to alternate, to change people while doing something
examples_vi: During the trip, Darlene and I took turns driving so that neither of us would tire out. I have to make sure that my two sons take turns playing the video game.

definition_vi: to begin to do or study, to undertake
examples_vi: After today's exam, the class will be ready to take up the last chapter in the book. The piano takes up too much space in our living room. However, it would take too much time up to move it right now
so we'd better wait until later.

definition_vi: to consult someone about an important matter
examples_vi: Can I take the problem up with you right now? It's quite urgent. I can't help you with this matter. You'll have to take it up with the manager.

definition_vi: to answer in a rude manner, to speak disrespectfully
examples_vi: Billy, if you talk back to me like that once more, you're going to spend the rest of the day in your room. The school principal had to reprimand the child for talking back to her teacher.

definition_vi: to discuss or consider a situation with others
examples_vi: We talked over Carla's plan to install an air conditioner in the room, but we couldn't reach a decision. Before I accepted the new job offer, I talked the matter over with my wife.

definition_vi: to destroy by making flat, to demolish
examples_vi: The construction company had to tear down the old hotel in order to build a new office building. The owners had to tear the house down after it burned down in a fire.

definition_vi: to rip into small pieces
examples_vi: Deidre tore up the letter angrily and threw all the pieces into the trash can. He told the lawyer to tear the old contract up and then to prepare a new one.

definition_vi: to distinguish between
examples_vi: The two brothers look so much alike that few people can tell them apart. That copy machine is so good that I can't pick the photocopy and the original apart. Most new cars are very similar in appearance. It's almost impossible to tell one from another.

definition_vi: to have a opinion of
examples_vi: I don't think much of him as a baseball player
he's a slow runner and a poor hitter. James thinks highly of his new boss, who is a kind and helpful person.

definition_vi: to consider carefully before deciding
examples_vi: I'd like to think over your offer first. Then can we talk it over tomorrow? You don't have to give me your decision now. Think it over for a while.

definition_vi: to invent, to create
examples_vi: Who thought up the idea of painting the living room walls bright red? When asked by the teacher why she was late, the student dreamed up a plausible excuse.

definition_vi: to discard, to dispose of
examples_vi: I generally throw away my clothes when I wear them out. Don't throw the magazines away
I haven't read them yet.

definition_vi: to discard
examples_vi: Instead of throwing out our paper waste in the office, we should recycle it. When a fight broke out between two people on the dance floor, the management threw them out. The judge threw the case out because there was insufficient evidence to try the defendant successfully.

definition_vi: to introduce an unexpected topic, causing embarrassment
examples_vi: The first week of class was going very well until a student threw the teacher a curve by suggesting that the textbook was too difficult. The director asked us in advance to stick to the meeting agenda and not to throw him any curves.

definition_vi: to punish with full penalty, to be harsh on
examples_vi: Because the criminal was a repeat offender, the judge threw the book at him with heavy fines and a long prison term. My boss threw the book at me when he discovered that I had been using company time for personal business. I was severely reprimanded and forced to make up the lost time.

definition_vi: to erect or construct quickly
examples_vi: The Red Cross threw up temporary shelters for the homeless victims of the earthquake. The ill patient is unable to digest her food properly, so she is throwing all of it up.

definition_vi: to make very weary due to difficult conditions or hard effort
examples_vi: The hot weather tired out the runners in the marathon. Does studying for final exams wear you out? It makes me feel worn out!

definition_vi: to receive credit for the value of an old item towards the purchase of a new item
examples_vi: The car dealership offered me $1,000 for my old car if I traded it in for a new model. The appliance company was offering a $50 trade-in during the special promotion for its new line of refrigerators.

definition_vi: to wear clothes to check the style or fit before buying
examples_vi: He tried on several suits before he picked out a blue one. Why don't you try these shoes on next?

definition_vi: to test, to use during a trial period
examples_vi: You can try out the new car before you decide to buy it. I can let you try the computer out for a few days before you make a decision.

definition_vi: to move or face in the opposite direction
examples_vi: The man turned his car around and drove back the way he came. The company has been very successful since the new business manager was able to turn it around.

definition_vi: to reduce in brightness or volume
examples_vi: Please turn down the radio for me. It's too loud while I'm studying. Laverne wanted to join the military but the recruiting officer turned her application down because Laverne is hard of hearing in one ear.

definition_vi: to cause to stop functioning
examples_vi: Please turn off the light when you leave the room. Are you really listening to the radio, or should I turn it off?

definition_vi: to start or cause to function
examples_vi: Please turn on the light
it's too dark in here. Do you know who turned the air conditioning on?

definition_vi: to interest greatly, to excite
examples_vi: Does great art turn you on? I find going to a museum and viewing classic works of art a real turnon. Going to a bar and having silly conversation with strangers really turns me off. In fact, most bar scenes are really turnoffs to me.

definition_vi: to become or result; to appear, to attend
examples_vi: Most parents wonder how their children will turn out as adults. Hundreds of people came out for the demonstration against new taxes. What was the turnout for the public hearing on the education reforms?

definition_vi: to place upside down
examples_vi: The teacher asked the students to turn the answer sheet over and to write a short essay on the back. The car was going too fast around the corner and turned over twice. Mr. Collins has decided to turn over his jewelry store to his son at the end of the year.

definition_vi: risky, uncertain until the end
examples_vi: The complicated medical operation was touch and go for several hours. The outcome of the soccer final was touch and go for the entire match.

definition_vi: to serve in a store or restaurant
examples_vi: A very pleasant young clerk waited on me in that shop. The restaurant waitress asked us, "Has anyone waited on you yet?"

definition_vi: to wait until late at night without going to bed
examples_vi: Don't wait up for me. I may be back after midnight. We waited up for our son until two o'clock in the morning before we called the police.

definition_vi: to arise from sleep, to awaken
examples_vi: Marge woke up this morning very early, but she did not get up until about ten o'clock. My alarm clock wakes me up at the same time every day.

definition_vi: not be able to convince someone
examples_vi: Don't argue with Frank any longer. You are wasting your breath trying to get him to agree with you. I have already decided what I'm going to do. You can't change my mind, so save your breath.

definition_vi: to become worn gradually through use
examples_vi: If you drag your feet while you walk, you'll wear down your shoes quickly. The pounding of ocean waves against the coast gradually wears it away. Johnny has worn through the seat of his pants. Helga threw away that dress because she had worn it out.

definition_vi: to disappear gradually
examples_vi: My headache isn't serious. It will wear off after an hour or so. The effect of the painkilling drug didn't wear off for several hours.

definition_vi: to use something until it has no value or worth anymore, to make useless through wear
examples_vi: When I wear out these shoes, I'll have to buy some that last longer. What do you do with your clothes after you wear them out?

definition_vi: to exercise; to develop, to devise
examples_vi: Jane works out at the fitness center every other morning before going to school. The advertising department worked out a plan to increase company sales. We couldn't come up with a good plan for solving the problem, but we agreed to work it out at a later date.

definition_vi: not feeling well, sick
examples_vi: John stayed home from work because he was feeling under the weather. When you catch cold, you feel under the weather.

definition_vi: with the upper side turned toward the lower side
examples_vi: The accident caused one car to turn upside down, its wheels spinning in the air. One of the students was only pretending to read her textbook
the teacher could see that the book was actually upside down.

definition_vi: modern, current, timely
examples_vi: The president insisted that the company bring its aging equipment up to date. This catalog is not up to date. It was published several years ago. The news program gave an up-to-date account of the nuclear accident. The newscaster said that he would update the news report every half hour.

definition_vi: formerly did, had the habit of
examples_vi: I used to live in New York, but I moved to California two years ago. Kim used to smoke cigarettes, but she stopped the habit last month.

definition_vi: prefer to
examples_vi: Would you rather have the appointment this Friday or next Monday? I would just as soon go for a walk as watch TV right now.
